MD REVIEWS


Edward Banks

III dHC1SIll ClNl11Zdl1Oil WIN WCilC
near and far carrying the latest
message to the trans-space re-
lays via Telstar, man has always
had a nose for the news.


We wait for the latest release.
We watch for the most recent
telecast. We dial for telephone
item. We check with the daily
papers city desk when in doubt.
We read and re-read old maya
zines hoping to find some over


Over the radio we perhaps get
more news than ever. Every
half hour, every fifteen minutes
some newscaster or would be
newscaster Is relating the events
Of the time.


In the past three four or five
years news reporting has under
gone some radical changes. Once
upon a time the news reports
we're soberly disseminated by
men speaking in rapidly clipped
styles. The news was given with
out too much flair except for the
personal touches of announcers
like Gabriel Heater, Walter Win
chell, Lowell Thomas or H. V.
Kaltenborn.


These men kept listeners glued
to the radio while they read all
kinds of news items. Even Jim
ME Fidler, who dealt mainly in
Hollywood chatter was in
teresting. One woman was heard
now and then, she was Hedda
Hopper.


Today the newscasters are
vying for acting awards or for
the best all around comic Of the
year. dislike hearing so much
inane chatter when want to hear
news.


can sympathize with Walter
Cronkite, who does an excellent
and near Unconditional pre-
sentation of national and inter-
national events. He will be
replaced by a team in the coming
Democratic national party con-
vention at Atlantic City. ltseems
as though his ratings we're ruined
by the Bobbsey Twins Of Tele-
vision-Huntley and Brinkley.


| am one Of those ear weary
news hounds, who Is very tired
Of the toothy mumblings Of the
news analysts and commentators.
Chef and David, that award win
ming team of television fame
would do better in a weekly
private eye series. Both are so
SNUG and charming that they
could solve mystery in the half
hour time which they now devote
to presenting news.


On the other hand Huntley and
Brinkley could even fill in a
few engagements for Red Shelton
or Bob Hope. Some of their
Jokes are funnier than George
Burns or Jack Bennys.


This trend toward a duet Of
newscasters has run the gamut
at the local Phoenix level. On
some city television stations not
only two persons are on call
for the daily news. but three and
sometimes four. There is really
only enough material for one an
nouncer, however, the releases
are cut and patched and stretched
for three smiling males to read
(often misread).


A woman read few lines this
week she is our city's answer
to the Today shows Maureen
OSullivan (who was certainly
more appealing as Tarzan's
Jane).


Have you grown tired of waking
up to the dentine grins of Hugh
Downs, Jack Lescoulie and Frank

caution maintain the strict neutrality between iugants

taken writing under oath affirmation. before
officer of the

officer. Generally officer of the law who is authorized ad

examination is heard may take dispositions.


The officer taking the dispositions be interested
litigation He be the counsel for either
Of the parties in the be directly employed by counsel for
party financially interested in the action.


pointed that while in
the strict the notary taking deposition not acting
judicial officer he acting substitute of the
The testimony taken by admissible evidence
that he should be interested
the result of the litigation


duty employee his employer faithfully,

be called notarie in taking testimony
which their employers directly Interested

ling is a major sports event at the local
sports arena. Portions of the bouts are

chtde many WOnaen and children.


Weekly interviews with leading contendevs
and their opponents bYoUide breaks in the
sometimes vevy duh affairs. In several
instances, the WYestleYS haze engaged in
imbYowbtu ski1miShes causing the an
nounceY to move aside.


ON Monday night one Of the most desbic-
able scenes Of inlaunaan behavior 1Uas nit
messed Uaen tho men beat, Dashed, stamped
md b4n1naelled a popular WYeStleT He
WaS stunned and bloody When his partner as
sisted him to the dressing room. Several
stitches WeYe required to close his head
WOal,1dS.


Are ne to share the responsibility for such
scenes Of violence under the g7tiSe Of a sport?
What type of fair play and love ola sport
can be taught to our youth Wh0 watch such
shows? What does our state athletic COM
mission do during these acts Of brutal beat
ingS Haze ne forgotten that the German
society under Hitler turned deaf ear wlaen
the Jews we're being extey7ninated?


These UYesthqg bouts in the Valley bYoUide
little for vieoOeYs except the type of street
FIGHTING that does not need any referee or
televiSiOn cameras.
